Black Phoenix

Seriously....*sigh*
 
 This is what's so irritating....I mean if you want to be gay...go be gay...heck you know what..even if you want to marry...go marry...it'll never be enough for any of you due to the fact that the general populace doesn't want to recognize the fact it is supposedly normal to be gay or it's a biological thing....you can flaunt it all you want..but it's not going to bring acceptance of the homosexual lifestyle...it'll probably aggrevate people, especially old school conservatives the most only enciting the cycle to continue.

it'll probably aggrevate people, especially old school conservatives the most only enciting the cycle to continue.

 
 Actually, it aggrevates even those who support gay rights, myself included.

 haha, i'd nothing thought I'd see the day when Sigma was on par with my thinking.

haha, i'd nothing thought I'd see the day when Sigma was on par with my thinking.

 
 emoticon_ic I think hell has frozen over!
JakeCJB

Actually, it aggrevates even those who support gay rights, myself included.

 
 How can you agree with a condescending statement towards gay people like that, and also say you support gay rights?
Sigma

How can you agree with a condescending statement towards gay people like that, and also say you support gay rights?

 
 Condescending attitude? Is it truly condescending to say that something irritates me? I think its disgusting to celebrate who you have sex with. I would be equally disgusted if there was a "straight parade". There is no contempt on my part, merely anger.
 
 And yes, I fully support adoption rights for gay couples and marriage for gay couples. But I am disgusted with some group's attitudes that there is something special or holy or uncorruptable with having sex with someone of the same gender. Get over yourself. Yes I understand celebrating that you are no longer oppressed, but honestly I don't see that celebration happening.
 
 What I see this type of behavior doing is following the road of Affirmative Action and gay people having the eternal victim mentality that some women groups and black groups currently have, and it irritates me.
Matthew S

And yes, I fully support adoption rights for gay couples and marriage for gay couples. But I am disgusted with some group's attitudes that there is something special or holy or uncorruptable with having sex with someone of the same gender. Get over yourself. Yes I understand celebrating that you are no longer oppressed, but honestly I don't see that celebration happening.
 
 

 
 
 First off thankyou for your support :)
 
 Second striaght couples spend 1000's and sometimes 10's of thousands of dollars celebrating who they are having sex with. It is all over the place and on television. There is even a show called bridezilla. The hypocrisy is that if someone says they support gays and lesbians getting married then do not treat them the same as straight couples. I know many straight people who have told me they are getting married and expect, as their due and entitlement, that I will be happy, excited for, and congratulat them. It is a different story for gay and lesbian people for the same people that expect my to be excited for them do not give me the same respect and are not happy and excited for me. They sometimes sound disgusted and put out; yet the still want my acceptance, approval , and congratulations for their marriage.
JakeCJB

Condescending attitude?

 
 The original post from Phoenix was telling gay people their place, and what their expectations ought to be(low). Yes, I took it as condescending, and wasn't specifically sure what you were agreeing with.
 
 
Is it truly condescending to say that something irritates me? I think its disgusting to celebrate who you have sex with. I would be equally disgusted if there was a "straight parade". There is no contempt on my part, merely anger.

 
 Gay people don't have equal rights, and they still don't see themselves refelcted daily in mainstream society, as heteroexuals do. The entire visibility is less for gay people compared to straight people. Straight people have no more need for events which celebrate who they are, than white people have that need. As acceptance grows, there may be a need for less specifically gay events and groups. Perhaps people will keep the parade around, because it is simply fun. Why be angry about it? Why not lighten up and enjoy life? No one says you must attend. How would you feel about social events that are not parades, such as pride picnics? In a world where people are assumed to be straight, people who are gay don't have the same opportunities to meet one another, either. This is another reality gay people face. There are many gay people who don't like bars or clubs.
 
 
and yes, I fully support adoption rights for gay couples and marriage for gay couples. But I am disgusted with some groups attitudes that there is something special or holy or uncorruptable with having sex with someone of the same gender. Get over yourself.

 
 I don't understand why you are so angry about this. At the same time, I can respect your view that seems to be for gay people to seamlessly blend with the straight majority. The thing is, those of us who are gay do have a different history, and face a different reality. A different culture can develop from such an experience of otherness from the majority. Here, with gay people, it is the experience of being a sexual minority.
jyoshu

Second striaght couples spend 1000's and sometimes 10's of thousands of dollars celebrating who they are having sex with. It is all over the place and on television. There is even a show called bridezilla.
 
 
 I have news for you . . . that ain't celebration. It's called making money. 
 
 'Cause, believe it or not, sex sells.
 
 
The thing is, those of us who are gay do have a different history, and face a different reality. A different culture can develop from such an experience of otherness from the majority. Here, with gay people, it is the experience of being a sexual minority.

 
 Is an identity wrapped in who you have sex with really the sort of cultural identity you want? emoticon_wow If so, your movement is doing it spectacularly well.
JakeCJB

Let me say, I was at one gay pride parade, only one. It was specifically in support of equal marriage for same-sex couples. The feeling of unity among so many other gay people was amazing. It was a great, positive, feeling. It's not about being dirty or naughty, nor about sex acts. Only other gay people will understand this. Not someone who makes ignorant comments such as the following....
 
 
I have news for you . . . that ain't celebration. It's called making money. 
 
 'Cause, believe it or not, sex sells.
 
 
 
 Is an identity wrapped in who you have sex with really the sort of cultural identity you want? emoticon_wow If so, your movement is doing it spectacularly well.

 
 Jyoshu, it goes beyond that. I mean, wow, is that all you got from my post, attempting to inform you of what it is like as part of the gay minority? Holy mccrap, are you really that willfully blind, ignorant, or weirdly focused on people's sex acts? Marginalizing a minority will cause that minority to develop their own culture, to draw together for survival, to have a shared common experience. The fact that it involves sexuality in this case, means what to you? That this minority is dirty, and you rub your hands together with glee with a big grin on your face? GROW UP!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Sigma

First off thankyou for your support :)

 
 You're welcome :) My brother-in-law is gay, and I would not support anything that would make him a second-class citizen.
 
 

 Second striaght couples spend 1000's and sometimes 10's of thousands of dollars celebrating who they are having sex with. It is all over the place and on television. There is even a show called bridezilla. The hypocrisy is that if someone says they support gays and lesbians getting married then do not treat them the same as straight couples. I know many straight people who have told me they are getting married and expect, as their due and entitlement, that I will be happy, excited for, and congratulat them. It is a different story for gay and lesbian people for the same people that expect my to be excited for them do not give me the same respect and are not happy and excited for me. They sometimes sound disgusted and put out; yet the still want my acceptance, approval , and congratulations for their marriage.

 
 Yes, you are right and it is perfectly legitimate to call those who wish congrats but do not give them hypocrites. Reality shows in general I have contempt for, so you will not see me condoning anything they do.
 
 Forgive me if I mispell or say something weird, I'm slightly drunk.
 
 

 The original post from Phoenix was telling gay people their place, and what their expectations ought to be(low). Yes, I took it as condescending, and wasn't specifically sure what you were agreeing with.

 
 First off, thank you for your conciliatory attitude. I come off strong sometimes and I do not usually intend to offend.
 
 The original sentiment expressed by Phoenix was resignation, which I do agree with in terms of the entire "gay pride" phenome.
 
 

 Gay people don't have equal rights, and they still don't see themselves refelcted daily in mainstream society, as heteroexuals do. The entire visibility is less for gay people compared to straight people. Straight people have no more need for events which celebrate who they are, than white people have that need.

 
 Agreed, and visibility is needed to get the message out. However, what I see is not "getting the message out", it is... reveling in skimpy outfits and outdoing each other with outrageous behavior. I would be ecstatic if gay people would be part of the community as normal people, but I genuinely fear that this sort of behavior and message of "look at us, we are different" will overwhelm and overpower the true message of "we are just like you". It disgusts and irritates me.
 
 

 As acceptance grows, there may be a need for less specifically gay events and groups.

 
 And this is part of what makes me angry, I do not believe that will happen judging by todays behavior. I understand these events for celebrating freedom from oppression, but there comes a point (and I think it's past this point) where such displays are counterproductive.
 
 

 Perhaps people will keep the parade around, because it is simply fun. Why be angry about it? Why not lighten up and enjoy life? No one says you must attend. How would you feel about social events that are not parades, such as pride picnics? In a world where people are assumed to be straight, people who are gay don't have the same opportunities to meet one another, either. This is another reality gay people face. There are many gay people who don't like bars or clubs.

 
 I object because they are so public. A gathering of like-minded individuals in a picnic would not bother me in the slightest. A public display proclaiming "look at me look at me I'm gay" strikes me as childish and grandstanding. The outfits disgust me, and the commercialization saddens me. If your message is "I'm just like everyone else" don't work on separating yourself. This is part of the reason some black groups and women groups have lost any sympathy I had for them, they work so hard to separate themselves yet complain when they're treated differently. This is the road I fear for those who are gay.
 
 I'm sorry if this didn't make sense, I'm slightly drunk.
jyoshu

Jyoshu, it goes beyond that. I mean, wow, is that all you got from my post, attempting to inform you of what it is like as part of the gay minority? 

 
 What the heck else is it about then? What else do you have to point to for a cultural identity? It's not like it's skin color, ethnic background, beliefs, a heritage, etc. Do you have "gay art?" How about traditional gay attire? You're talking about trying to fit some kind of 'proud cultural identity' into something that's ultimately about the fact that some men are simply turned on by men and some women are turned on by women. Whoopie!! I'm in awe. emoticon_rolleyes 
 
 
Marginalizing a minority will cause that minority to develop their own culture, to draw together for survival, to have a shared common experience. The fact that it involves sexuality in this case, means what to you? That this minority is dirty, blah blah blah 

 
 I didn't say anything about anything being "dirty"--that's your words, not mine. You have quite an imagination about the "glee" part. But if you think people in general view your movement in terms of a cultural identity instead of simply some people being attracted to people of their own gender (which is ultimately all it is) then I have some swamp land for sale. And exactly what cultural heritage do you think parades with sexual overtones, lewd acting, and some scantily-dressed people (in the parades) is going to get across? Who do you think you're kidding, here?
 
 Say, how 'bout showing me some of that traditional gay folk art from your heritage, would you? Maybe even a traditional gay folk dance. emoticon_rolleyes
JakeCJB

What the heck else is it about then? What else do you have to point to for a cultural identity? It's not like it's skin color, ethnic background, beliefs, a heritage, etc. Do you have "gay art?" You're talking about trying to fit some kind of 'proud cultural identity' into something that's ultimately about the fact that some men are simply turned on by men and some women are turned on by women.  I didn't say anything about anything being "dirty"--that's your words, not mine. You have quite an imagination about the "glee" part.  Say, how 'bout showing me some of that traditional gay folk art from your heritage, would you? Maybe even a traditional gay folk dance. emoticon_rolleyes

 
 My goodness, don't you know it all. There is no such thing as gay culture, it's just about who you are turned on by(at least this time you said it was about more than physical acts). At any rate, I am glad we have you here to inform us that's all it is. Maybe you could tell that to the many fine universities such as Yale, Brown, the University of Chicago, Berkley, etc., which offer studies in gay cultures(notice how the term itself is used in the descriptions on this page)...
 
 http://www.yale.edu/lesbiangay/Pages/Community/OtherPrgms.html
 
 Scantily clad people? Well, that happens in Mardi Gras too. The Dallas Cowboys cheerleaders, female professional wrestlers, music videos, Hooter's Restaurants, the sales of posters of bikini girls for college dorm rooms, Sports Illunstrated Swimsuit issue, Victoria's secret...on and on. That's mainly for straight men, however.
jyoshu

Maybe you could tell that to the many fine universities such as Yale, Brown, the University of Chicago, Berkley, etc., which offer studies in gay cultures(notice how the term itself is used in the descriptions on this page)...

 
 Looks like mostly teaching on sexuality to me. But hey, what do I know? How on earth could I possibly think that homosexuality isn't a rich cultural background?

 But those aren't examples supposedly "celebrating" straight culture.

But those aren't examples supposedly "celebrating" straight culture.

 
 It's so accepted as part of the mainstream, it's not regarded that way.
jyoshu

Everthing is a celebration of striaght culture......everyday is straight pride day!

 
 Oh come on. There's nothing celebratory about it. Have you ever seen a "straight pride" parade?
 
 
It's so accepted as part of the mainstream, it's not regarded that way.

 
 You're right, but straight sexual overtones in culture (mostly just marketing) is not a point of pride. It's not a cutural heritage thing (or, as in the case of your movement--trying to pass itself off as a cultural heritage thing.)
joebrummer

Oh come on. There's nothing celebratory about it. Have you ever seen a "straight pride" parade?
 
 
 
 You're right, but straight sexual overtones in culture (mostly just marketing) is not a point of pride. It's not a cutural heritage thing (or, as in the case of your movement--trying to pass itself off as a cultural heritage thing.)

 Is there a reason to have a straight pride parade? DO we need to draw attention to straight people?
jyoshu

Is there a reason to have a straight pride parade? 

 
 No, which is sorta the point.
tonybrown74

No, which is sorta the point.

 
 Indeed, hence the gay pride parade.
 
 Many will take issue with the commercialism, and some will have issues with some of the costumes, but what peeves me about some of these responses to gay pride parades is the fact that they criticize the ENTIRE parade based on those issues.
 
 No one seems to want to talk about all the church groups that march in the parades. People ignore the politicians, the outreach groups, the youth groups and the supporters. There are family outings, music festivals, arts and crafts and even church services that occur.
 
 But no. People just love to focus on the g-strings, drag queens and the dykes on bikes. they don't even make up the plurality of pride parades, at least none that I have gone to.
jyoshu

Many will take issue with the commercialism, and some will have issues with some of the costumes, but what peeves me about some of these responses to gay pride parades is the fact that they criticize the ENTIRE parade based on those issues.

 
 Why should the parade organizers not be taken to task for allowing elements that make the gay pride movement look risque? One would think you would WANT this changed. If gay pride is "not sexual thing" as some of you seem to want everyone to think, then why have those elements at all? I don't see such things in St. Patrick's Day parades (which tend to celebrate Irish culture), or in events which celebrate African American heritage. If one or a few bad elements make the parade look bad, why should I not criticize the parade?
 
 
No one seems to want to talk about all the church groups that march in the parades. People ignore the politicians, the outreach groups, the youth groups and the supporters. There are family outings, music festivals, arts and crafts and even church services that occur.

 
 Those things don't have shock value. If you have an event that has a church group alongside people in g-strings (as you say), which do you think will get the attention? (Hint: it ain't the church group.) If you don't want them getting all the attention then it's quite simple: don't have them there to attract attention. Look, have your parades if you want, and have all the crazy stuff you want. But don't try to de-emphasize the sexual part of your movement or claim it's not about sex when at the same time you allow, even celebrate, these elements in your parades. It smacks of hypocrisy.
tonybrown74

Why should the parade organizers not be taken to task for allowing elements that make the gay pride movement look risque? One would think you would WANT this changed. If gay pride is "not sexual thing" as some of you seem to want everyone to think, then why have those elements at all? I don't see such things in St. Patrick's Day parades (which tend to celebrate Irish culture), or in events which celebrate African American heritage. If one or a few bad elements make the parade look bad, why should I not criticize the parade? 

 
 If those supposed elements aren't doing anything illegal, why should they take issue with them? And glbt people celebrate their sexuality because their sexuality is a part of who we are. It is what makes us different. It is THE reason why we are discriminated against.
 
 But you, and many like you assume that sexuality is the ONLY thing we're celebrating, which is the furthest thing from the truth. We celebrate our community, we celebrate our support for each other, we celebrate our health, our faith, our families and our friends. Most importantly, we celebrate our freedoms.
 
 
 Those things don't have shock value. If you have an event that has a church group alongside people in g-strings (as you say), which do you think will get the attention? (Hint: it ain't the church group.) If you don't want them getting all the attention then it's quite simple: don't have them there to attract attention. Look, have your parades if you want, and have all the crazy stuff you want. But don't try to de-emphasize the sexual part of your movement or claim it's not about sex when at the same time you allow, even celebrate, these elements in your parades. It smacks of hypocrisy.

 
 People at the parade applaud and cheer the church groups as well as the g-strings. The only people who really seem to focus on the more scandalous components of the parade are those who who have an agenda against the community's interests. And because of those people taking advantage the news media's apetite for shock value, those are the elements that get more attention.
 
 However have you noticed that even these elements seem to get less and less attention from the news media every year? Yet the parades still go on. The crowds still come and the whiny moralists continue to b*tch.
Steeeeve

Everthing is a celebration of striaght culture......everyday is straight pride day!

 
 ugh, no its not. This is the same answer I get when I ask "why is there a black cultural center but no white cultural center" to which the response is "The US is the white cultural center". But as a matter of fact, it isn't.

ugh, no its not. This is the same answer I get when I ask "why is there a black cultural center but no white cultural center" to which the response is "The US is the white cultural center". But as a matter of fact, it isn't.

Cultural heritage and marketing are two different things.

 
 Look up, jyoshu. That thing you see flying over your head is the point that you clearly missed.
 
 Images from TV, movies, magazines and billoards affect the psyche of those of who are not represented or represented in a negative light. 
 
 I can tell you, many a little black girl will play with a towel on their heads pretending to have nice long hair because they see nothing but women with nice, long hair in commecials and on TV. Little girls stuffing their bras because women with large breasts idolized on TV. Bulimia and anorexia are problems because we idolize thin people on TV.
 
 The blind can see this. Why can't you?
jyoshu

Look up, jyoshu. That thing you see flying over your head is the point that you clearly missed.

 
 Whatever, dude. Regardless of whatever "point" you're making here, it's obivously not about cultural heritage. We've been talking about whether or not there is a gay cultural heritage or not, and whether or not it's sexual-based. If you want to discuss marketing and fads, go for it.
tonybrown74
